National protest underway
Protest against the war in
Vietnam is mount lug. is students
prepare for massive protests tlns
weekend and next week.
Baltimore County police
moved into the campus of Towson State College this morning at
4:00, arresting 19 students who
had occupied Lithictim Hall since
shortly after midnight.
Campus security police proclaimed an "emergency situation — shortly after the group, at
first numbering.40 students,
moved into Lithicum with large
amounts of food and water.
Other activity in Baltimore,
apart from tonight's
University-wide meeting here, is
centered in Monday's rally, slated
to begin in Wyman Park at 3 p.m.
Protesters will march to Federal
Plaza, where Baltimore Citizens
for Social Justice is preparing a
list of speakers.
In Washington, where a
round-the-clock vigil continues in
front of the White House, a rally
will be held Saturday by the
Mall's reflecting pool.

In Baltimore, yesterday's
activity included a meeting of
100 students and administrations
in front of Levering Hall. and a
peaceful rally of several hundred
in Federal Plaza.
Seven hundred students from
Towson State marched through
t hat city in a candle -lit
procession last night. One
observer called the march "very
peaceful. very orderly, very
drama t ic.""
Today. at daybreak, students
from St . Mary's College, in
Chesapeake City. began a 68-mile
treck to Washington, where they
will arrive in time for Saturday's
activity.

diligence revived
The new phase of the United States policy in Viet
Na mrecently implemented by President Nixon has solidified and enlarged analready tremendous group of citizens who oppose the Administration's conduct of its
Indochina adventure. Now, more than ever before, A—
mericans clearly have a mandate for the active and visible
expression of their indignation.
There no longer exists any excuse for Hopkins students to ignore this imperative. The Academic Council's
recommendations have moved to eliminate scholastic
obstacles to timely political expression.
Many courses of action have been outlined to effect
change in the nation's foreign policy: all of these have
failed individually in the past. The time is right for
action, as the time has been right so frequently before. Many methods have failed, hut the method of
all-out attack on all fronts has never failed—it has never
been tried. This diversified approach should be coupled
with another strategy which has never been executed
before: a sustained, long-term drive, not for a weekend,
not for a week, not when the weather is nice, but until
the government makes its policies coincident with the
desires of its citizens.
This sort of action, when many claim the anti-war
movement is dying, would show those currently in
power that change roust be implemented. Hopkins students have the opportunity co take the lead in this
movement. Silence is acquiescence.

An open letter to all
Undergraduates, Graduates.
Faculty and Administration:
Tonight. at 7:30 pm., in the.
Great Hall of Levering there will
be - a meeting for all people
interested in participating in the
lobbying effort that will be going
on in Washington next week. The
meeting will be organizational in
nature concerning such topics as
lobbying.strategy. transportation
to Washington. times, places. etc.
Announcements of this sort
bring back memories of 1970 and
Cambodia. Usually these
memories are marred by a feeling
of fiustration, knowing that we
did our best but ultimately
failed. However, there are two
differences between 1970 and
1972 that should give us new
hope.
The first difference is that
instead. of being disgruntled
students, we are now disgruntled
voters. After spending yesterday
in Washington. I realized what a
big difference this makes.
The second, and I think the
most important difference, is
that ill 1970 we felt that by
showing our dissatisfaction with
the war, the President would
somehow see fit to de-escalate it.
We now realize that Mr. Nixon
will not take the necessary steps
in that direction. Given this fact,
I feel that the most, effective
action we can take is to deter the
President via Congress, and this is
most effectively instituted
through lobbying.
Opposition to the war is
valuable on any level. Yesterday
the newly elected Student
Council issued a statement with
six suggestions for expressing
dissatisfaction. All six are valid
and many options were not
mentioned that are equally vaild.
This time we must realize that
expressing dissatisfaction in 1970

Opinion

Peace with McGovern
The only way in which
American military withdrawal
from Vietnam can be assured is
by the election of a President
who has consistently opposed the
War. Time and again we have
seen demonstrations against the
war, Congressional resolutions
calling for a withdrawl deadline,
and speeches from Richard
Nixon promising an end to the
fighting. The war continues
because the Commander in Chief
of the United States, despite
public opinion, is unwilling to
preside over what he perceives as
an American surrender.
It is extremely uncertain that
we can ever expect total
withdraw! while Richard Nixon is
President. The President's
reaction to the failure of
Vietnamization has been to
escalate the war to an extremely
dangerous level. If we are to
depend on the stability of the
Thieu regime as the determinig
factor in our withdrawal rate, we
are likely to remain in Vietnam
for many years to
There is, however, one
come.
thing of which we can be certain.
If George McGovern were

President of the United States
today, there would not be one
American soldier left in Vietnam
as of the first of September 1st
of this year. As a man who has
opposed U.S. involvement in
Indochina since 1963, Senator
McGovern would end all our
aerial bombardment of Vietnam
immediately upon his
innauguration, and would
withdraw all our forces within
four months. He has proposed as
much several times in the Senate
with the McGovern-Hatfield
Disengagement Act.
A McGovern victory would
thus mean the end of our
involvement in Indochina, once
and for all. By working through
the electoral process, we can
replace the man who has
escalated this war with one who
will stop it. To support George
McGovern is to support a
realizeable chance for peace.
Ther can be no question after
the primaries in Wisconson,
Massachusetts, Ohio, and
Nebraska, that Senator
McGovern has an excellent
chance of winning the
Democratic nomination and

clfeating Richard Nixon in
November. His support has been
strong in all segments of the
population, rom blue collar
workers to students..Through the
work of thousands of volunteer
workers, McGovern has won
victories in areas where he had
been given no chance by the
press or political "pros." With a
similar effort in Maryland, the
Senator can make an excellent
showing here and pick up
additional delegates to the
convention.
Campaign workers are needed
daily, up to and including
election day. Activities include
door to door canvassing,
leafletting, and phone canvassing.
In addition, volunteers are
needed to hand out sample
ballots at the polls. Senator
McGovern will speak at 6 pm.
Saturday at the Merriweather
Post Pavillion in Columbia, and a
large turnout would greatly help
the campaign. To volunteer, stop
by McGovern headquarters at
817 N. Charles St. (phone
685-7718).
•

David Baron

terms is not enough. I feel we
must turn to the Congress which
has the Constitutional right and
duty to deter the President if the
American people deem it to be
necessary. and I believe they do.
Too long has Mr. Nixon been
basing his actions on a silent
majority. If we are to expect
Congress to act, we must tell it
how we feel. When Congressmen
find out that you can vote, they

They must listen, as their jobs

Opinion

Wide-based action
The an n ouncemen t of
President Nixon - has caused
people to once more think about
the war in Vietnam and its effect
not only on their own lives but
upon the well-being of all the
peoples of the world. In response
to a new escalation of the
conflict an effort is being made
to renew the anti-war movement
and make a strong protest. Yet
many of us do not know how to
do that.
Some people would like to
show their moral outrage by
fire-bombing ROTC buildings,
engaging in sit-ins and other
visible, but verbal,
demonstrations of
condemnation. Such actions no
longer serve a viable function.
Certainly, they provide an outlet
for justafiably enraged people,
but they fail to strike the heart
of the matter.
On Tuesday, May 9, people at
Hopkins began to meet to discuss
this problem and seek new
solutions. These people are held
together by the common
realization that it is necessary at
this time to move off campus and
organize a strong resistance on
the city, state, and national
levels. Such a movement, if it is
to succeed, must develop a
coherent policy for action. That
policy must involve members of
all classes within our society,
who realize that the war must
end immediately not only
because it is a moral outrage, but
also because it is a repressive,
reactionary, imperialistic
expression of the ruling class's
ideology. That policy causes

inflaction in this country and
death and destruction abroad.
Our problem is to determine
the best way to defeat that
policy and turn its advocates out
of office. Such a goal involves
time, money, and manpower resources which the members of
the Hopkins community possess.
Already an attempt is being made
to draw interested groups and
people together on a city-wide
le,vel to develop concrete
proposals for action which cover
the full spectrum of political
activity. People are needed to
participate in the planning,
people who are willing to work
toward contacting labor unions
and businessmen. If we work
hard and quickly, we may be able
to bring real economic pressure
to bear upon the government of
this country, to show them that
we know that the basis of the
war is economic, that we know
we will win not by filling the
jails, but by making them feel the
economic crunch to which they
have subjected the hard-working
citizens of this country. Only by
striking at the war machine in
this fashion can we hope to stop
it.
This discussion may seem
overly general, but it is necessary
if only for tactical reasons 7
that it be so. If you are interested
and wish to work, you can call
any of the following and leave
your name and phone number:

Mark Derr
Kermit Baker
Steve Asin

296-1552
235-8207
435-6419

Na mrecently implemented by President Nixon has solidified and enlarged analready tremendous group of citizens who oppose the Administration's conduct of its
Indochina adventure. Now, more than ever before, A—
mericans clearly have a mandate for the active and visible
expression of their indignation.
There no longer exists any excuse for Hopkins students to ignore this imperative. The Academic Council's
recommendations have moved to eliminate scholastic
obstacles to timely political expression.
Many courses of action have been outlined to effect
change in the nation's foreign policy: all of these have
failed individually in the past. The time is right for
action, as the time has been right so frequently before. Many methods have failed, hut the method of

with another strategy which has never been executed
before: a sustained, long-term drive, not for a weekend,
not for a week, not when the weather is nice, but until
the government makes its policies coincident with the
desires of its citizens.
This sort of action, when many claim the anti-war
movement is dying, would show those currently in
power that change roust be implemented. Hopkins students have the opportunity co take the lead in this
movement. Silence is acquiescence.

Opinion

Peace with McGovern
The only way in which
American military withdrawal
from Vietnam can be assured is
by the election of a President
who has consistently opposed the
War. Time and again we have
seen demonstrations against the
war, Congressional resolutions
calling for a withdrawl deadline,
and speeches from Richard
Nixon promising an end to the
fighting. The war continues
because the Commander in Chief
of the United States, despite
public opinion, is unwilling to
preside over what he perceives as
an American surrender.
It is extremely uncertain that
we can ever expect total
withdraw! while Richard Nixon is
President. The President's
reaction to the failure of
Vietnamization has been to
escalate the war to an extremely
dangerous level. If we are to
depend on the stability of the
Thieu regime as the determinig
factor in our withdrawal rate, we
are likely to remain in Vietnam
for many years to
There is, however, one
come.
thing of which we can be certain.
If George McGovern were

President of the United States
today, there would not be one
American soldier left in Vietnam
as of the first of September 1st
of this year. As a man who has
opposed U.S. involvement in
Indochina since 1963, Senator
McGovern would end all our
aerial bombardment of Vietnam
immediately upon his
innauguration, and would
withdraw all our forces within
four months. He has proposed as
much several times in the Senate
with the McGovern-Hatfield
Disengagement Act.
A McGovern victory would
thus mean the end of our
involvement in Indochina, once
and for all. By working through
the electoral process, we can
replace the man who has
escalated this war with one who
will stop it. To support George
McGovern is to support a
realizeable chance for peace.
Ther can be no question after
the primaries in Wisconson,
Massachusetts, Ohio, and
Nebraska, that Senator
McGovern has an excellent
chance of winning the
Democratic nomination and

clfeating Richard Nixon in
November. His support has been
strong in all segments of the
population, rom blue collar
workers to students..Through the
work of thousands of volunteer
workers, McGovern has won
victories in areas where he had
been given no chance by the
press or political "pros." With a
similar effort in Maryland, the
Senator can make an excellent
showing here and pick up
additional delegates to the
convention.
Campaign workers are needed
daily, up to and including
election day. Activities include
door to door canvassing,
leafletting, and phone canvassing.
In addition, volunteers are
needed to hand out sample
ballots at the polls. Senator
McGovern will speak at 6 pm.
Saturday at the Merriweather
Post Pavillion in Columbia, and a
large turnout would greatly help
the campaign. To volunteer, stop
by McGovern headquarters at
817 N. Charles St. (phone
685-7718).

Opinion

Wide-based action
The an n ouncemen t of
President Nixon - has caused
people to once more think about
the war in Vietnam and its effect
not only on their own lives but
upon the well-being of all the
peoples of the world. In response
to a new escalation of the
conflict an effort is being made
to renew the anti-war movement
and make a strong protest. Yet
many of us do not know how to
do that.
Some people would like to
show their moral outrage by
fire-bombing ROTC buildings,
engaging in sit-ins and other
visible, but verbal,
demonstrations of
condemnation. Such actions no
longer serve a viable function.
Certainly, they provide an outlet
for justafiably enraged people,
but they fail to strike the heart
of the matter.
On Tuesday, May 9, people at
Hopkins began to meet to discuss
this problem and seek new
solutions. These people are held
together by the common
realization that it is necessary at
this time to move off campus and
organize a strong resistance on
the city, state, and national
levels. Such a movement, if it is
to succeed, must develop a
coherent policy for action. That
policy must involve members of
all classes within our society,
who realize that the war must
end immediately not only
because it is a moral outrage, but
also because it is a repressive,
reactionary, imperialistic
expression of the ruling class's
ideology. That policy causes

inflaction in this country and
death and destruction abroad.
Our problem is to determine
the best way to defeat that
policy and turn its advocates out
of office. Such a goal involves
time, money, and manpower resources which the members of
the Hopkins community possess.
Already an attempt is being made
to draw interested groups and
people together on a city-wide
le,vel to develop concrete
proposals for action which cover
the full spectrum of political
activity. People are needed to
participate in the planning,
people who are willing to work
toward contacting labor unions
and businessmen. If we work
hard and quickly, we may be able
to bring real economic pressure
to bear upon the government of
this country, to show them that
we know that the basis of the
war is economic, that we know
we will win not by filling the
jails, but by making them feel the
economic crunch to which they
have subjected the hard-working
citizens of this country. Only by
striking at the war machine in
this fashion can we hope to stop
it.
This discussion may seem
overly general, but it is necessary
if only for tactical reasons 7
that it be so. If you are interested
and wish to work, you can call
any of the following and leave
your name and phone number:
